subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] lexical set: my set for general American English
msgSnippet: ... Okay, that makes sense. I myself distinguish between PALM and THOUGHT, and in fact would find it odd to see father spelled with On. ... I in fact
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>

>
> 1) I think that Ah is clearly superior to Ox for people who merge PALM
> + THOUGHT; the change is in fact one where the vowel of PALM has been
> adopted in the THOUGHT words too. Someone who distinguishes "palm" from
> "thought" will, I think be extremely confused to see "palm" written with
> Ox; it would suggest "Pom" (Australian slang for Brits). Whereas "thaht"
> can be written off as a "bloody Americanism".

Okay, that makes sense. I myself distinguish between PALM and THOUGHT,
and in fact would find it odd to see "father" spelled with "On."

>
> 2) Some Americans resolve NEAR = SQUARE in favor of NEAR (they say
> "squeer"), whereas others resolve it in favor of SQUARE (they say "nare").
> Both are minority viewpoints: the majority keep the distinction.
> This is going to be tricky.
>
> 3) Nobody fully merges KIT and DRESS; the neutralization in Southern
> American (and some forms of Californian) occurs before /n/ and /m/ only.
> I don't have a good plan for what to do about this.
>

> Here the trouble is that for *most* people this distinction (historically
> Awe/Owe) is also neutralized, but for dialects including Scottish, Irish,
> Eastern New England, and parts of the American South, these sounds are
> quite different: "horse" (NORTH) does not sound the same as "hoarse"
> (FORCE), nor is "for" (NORTH) like "four" (FORCE).


I in fact distinguish between "four" and "for." At work today I realized
that I distinguish between "far" "four" and "for," and might initially
be confused to see "four" spelled like "for."

But as you know, I have favor a bit of standardization, so I don't know
if some of the mergers are as problematic as they might seem. Even
though I am a very poor speller, I would never write "bear" when I meant
"beer." In the same way, it should not present too much of a problem for
me to remember to write these two words differently under QS. Others
argue against such rules because it means memorizing words by rote, a
practice that makes QS as bad as TO, but I don't think so. We are
talking about a small number of words for each dialect. Those dialects
that merge certain sets would have to become aware they do so and either
use a standard, or ignore and it probably be understood. No one would
misunderstand my meaning if I wrote Bob If Roar instead of Bob Ed Roar.

I suppose the difficulty comes because we would have to decide what
dialect to standardize on. For example, if the majority of speakers
merge "four" and "for," how does a Bostonian feel to have the
distinction between these words taken away? (Personally, I can see
myself getting use to this merger relatively easily.)

Writing, anyway, is a somewhat artificial convention. For one thing,
even QS does not represent how we speak, how we change sounds in a word
depending on its context. I became more aware of the difference between
written and spoken language from a book *Writing Systems*, which points
out (amongst other things), that the Chinese would never think of
reading a book aloud, because Chinese contains so many hononyms it might
become confusing, whereas the Chinese writing system distinguishes these
hononyms. So I argue that having QS may not be able to be constructed so
that everyone can write exactly as they hear words. For the most part,
users should be able to write QS this way, but their will be cases when
they cannot. Since Read has prescribed that It be used for "y" at the
end of a word, and since he states that the letter "r" should always be
written, QS has already developed some conventions of its own.

Back to the chart at hand. I agree with your proposal in the other
thread that we should use Awl Roar for those who merge words like
"North" and "Force." This is the convention already, and I see no reason
to change it.

I am surprised at the small number of objections you have raised about
my chart. So am I to assume it is at least a good start, that there are
no major fundamental flaws in it--or perhaps you think the NEAR SQUARE
and KIT DRESS are major problems right now?

One last note. If I am correct, the problems we are trying to solve can
be summarized thus:

1. What to do with mergers

2. What to do with dialects like Australian that make different
distinctions than RP or American English.

It seems that of the two problems, #1 is the main one, at least right
now, and that #2 can mostly be worked out (or perhaps already is worked
out).

Paul
